intro: Niphobolus tricuspe, commonly known as the three-lobed bladderwort, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibacillaceae. It is characterized by its tiny, bladder-like structures called pneumatocysts, which help it float and facilitate gas exchange. The plant typically grows in freshwater environments such as ponds and slow-moving streams. Its simple morphology includes filamentous stems and small, scale-like leaves. Niphobolus tricuspe is known for its ability to capture small aquatic organisms, contributing to its role as a predatory plant in its ecosystem.
